document.title: South Carolina Academic Standards and Performance Indicators for Science

E63EA5C6B74044F2BEA31E91B70C61B2.description:
Construct explanations for how structural adaptations (such as methods for defense,
locomotion, obtaining resources, or camouflage) allow animals to survive in the
environment.

1B87C64C087B404C80BB5F84D74B09D8.description:
Construct explanations for how structural adaptations (such as the types of roots, stems,
or leaves; color of flowers; or seed dispersal) allow plants to survive and reproduce.

8D49972D1C7C47489BC107DFD33751CB.description:
Develop and use models to compare how humans and other animals use their senses and
sensory organs to detect and respond to signals from the environment.

86DBE5318ECB4E818C7C04167B0B0AFF.description:
Plants and animals have physical characteristics that allow
them to receive information from the environment. Structural adaptations within groups of plants
and animals allow them to better survive and reproduce.

285F3DF5DDA045508BC0230FDFD2E8CF.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support claims that some characteristics of organisms
are inherited from parents and some are influenced by the environment.

04AE24A35CEB4B72ACC754A14105552A.description:
Develop and use models to compare the stages of growth and development in various
animals.

C9B7D34ECB91493B8EAD589A39FB2612.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements to compare the stages
of development of different seed plants.

67AD859DCCF14ECBAD5151661BE33B9C.description:
Obtain and communicate information about the characteristics of plants and animals to
develop models which classify plants as flowering or nonflowering and animals as
vertebrate or invertebrate.

90070E74B47B46749C16EA4BCBBBF10E.description:
Scientists have identified and classified many types of plants
and animals. Each plant or animal has a unique pattern of growth and development called a life
cycle. Some characteristics (traits) that organisms have are inherited and some result from
interactions with the environment.

7F7BA5E2E60C482A91BD51F9FE7B18D7.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of how the structural
characteristics and traits of plants and animals allow them to survive, grow, and reproduce.

3A3C495699F14616BDF72C74DA4B26CD.description: Life Science: Characteristics and Growth of Organisms

965B4572F72B4EB98A71A96D63B9F506.description:
Define problems related to the communication of information over a distance and design
devices or solutions that use sound to solve the problem.

A237C5FE71C749F4BC9D296EBCDC7500.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements to describe how
changes in vibration affects the pitch and volume of sound.

A55738B92E3E4796B3C347462856B99A.description:
Plan and conduct scientific investigations to test how different variables affect the
properties of sound (including pitch and volume).

63A95C1B2C234B87930AFBEF47A8ECE5.description:
Sound, as a form of energy, is produced by vibrating objects
and has specific properties including pitch and volume. Sound travels through air and other
materials and is used to communicate information in various forms of technology.

7A168409A99848C7A602242BC23AF2F5.description:
Plan and conduct scientific investigations to explain how light behaves when it strikes
transparent, translucent, and opaque materials.

A5B5C742287A42599FAD0F75D07BEA66.description:
Develop and use models to describe how light travels and interacts when it strikes an
object (including reflection, refraction, and absorption) using evidence from
observations.

B200925DCAA745DD8BDA589B8B79A361.description:
Obtain and communicate information to explain how the visibility of an object is related
to light.

5B4B6F7D62874C409CA753C6292B4DED.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations and measurements to describe how the
apparent brightness of light can vary as a result of the distance and intensity of the light
source.

E6740527055C471D9D70E21536F67DD7.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support the claim that white light is made up of
different colors.

30404424B1C441A98CEFA3811F5C9D97.description:
Light, as a form of energy, has specific properties including
color and brightness. Light travels in a straight line until it strikes an object. The way light reacts
when it strikes an object depends on the object’s properties.

F9DD4A3583B047D4B18819A25D6C9B4F.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the properties of light and sound
as forms of energy.

F521E1B3DB524276892D62117EFC67BB.description: Physical Science: Forms of Energy - Light and Sound

7815BF8CF1EC46F39B8EE60404EF3FCC.description:
Develop and use models to describe the factors (including tilt, revolution, and angle of
sunlight) that result in Earth’s seasonal changes.

53850A71D1BD4547AC2E2FA80FBFA9A5.description:
Construct explanations of how the Sun appears to move throughout the day using
observations of shadows.

B0766C45DEE546B0A37EE7955D815000.description: Construct explanations of how day and night result from Earth’s rotation on its axis.

C85EE6B459C249CB9F764F3BCC459D48.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations to describe patterns in the (1) location, (2)
movement, and (3) appearance of the Moon throughout the year.

C7656B9D274F4DE38CD73532F5743C91.description:
Earth orbits around the Sun and the Moon orbits around
Earth. These movements together with the rotation of Earth on a tilted axis result in patterns that
can be observed and predicted.

E9D1E864AD944E269BB0D3FE165FF0AF.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support claims about the importance of astronomy in
navigation and exploration (including the use of telescopes, astrolabes, compasses, and
sextants).

0CA0ACFEFF0041D3BC3406B2B451580D.description:
Obtain and communicate information to describe how constellations (including Ursa
Major, Ursa Minor, and Orion) appear to move from Earth’s perspective throughout the
seasons.

A1C97319D8AB4BC088F6B4B46CE0897C.description:
Develop and use models of Earth’s solar system to exemplify the location and order of
the planets as they orbit the Sun and the main composition (rock or gas) of the planets.

F16B5EBC9AAA42AA997D34D5CE7560DF.description:
Astronomy is the study of objects in our solar system and
beyond. A solar system includes a sun, (star), and all other objects that orbit that sun. Planets in our
night sky change positions and are not always visible from Earth as they orbit our Sun. Stars that are
beyond the solar system can be seen in the night sky in patterns called constellations. Constellations
can be used for navigation and appear to move together across the sky because of Earth’s rotation.

03C5FCF13B634553A9E7017926D4CFA4.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the locations, movements, and
patterns of stars and objects in the solar system.

B1A3A70744B647A4807D89EAC5E15268.description: Earth Science: Stars and the Solar System

48402120A53F43D285085764FADBEA08.description:
Construct explanations about regional climate differences using data from the long term
weather conditions of the region.

FDBDBC8C19374FEDAE0DE0C1F0E37802.description:
Obtain and communicate information about severe weather phenomena (including
thunderstorms, hurricanes, and tornadoes) to explain steps humans can take to reduce the
impact of severe weather phenomena.

EB5C36A795354C86BF84501FFCF2CC6C.description:
Analyze and interpret data from observations, measurements, and weather maps to
describe patterns in local weather conditions (including temperature, precipitation, wind
speed/direction, relative humidity, and cloud types) and predict changes in weather over
time.

D849DC205E21475CB42A13A88134F349.description:
Scientists record patterns in weather conditions across time
and place to make predictions about what kind of weather might occur next. Climate describes the
range of an area’s typical weather conditions and the extent to which those conditions vary over
long periods of time. Some weather conditions lead to severe weather phenomena that have
different effects and safety concerns.

D21C2D2CD7E54CED879592DA9234D463.description:
Develop and use models to explain how water changes as it moves between the
atmosphere and Earth’s surface during each phase of the water cycle (including
evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and runoff).

05B49064B3A24E39A51738D0B75C81F1.description:
Obtain and communicate information about some of the gases in the atmosphere
(including oxygen, nitrogen, and water vapor) to develop models that exemplify the
composition of Earth’s atmosphere where weather takes place.

6B3F17160007478EBF2CCBB503393259.description:
Earth’s atmosphere is a mixture of gases, including water
vapor and oxygen. The movement of water, which is found almost everywhere on Earth including
the atmosphere, changes form and cycles between Earth’s surface and the air and back again. This
cycling of water is driven by energy from the Sun. The movement of water in the water cycle is a
major pattern that influences weather conditions. Clouds form during this cycle and various types of
precipitation result.

42A06D93366D4E30A633FD65C9D86892.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the water cycle and weather and
climate patterns.

C0B99DE24BE342AE9283BB420F723B10.description:
Construct devices or design solutions to solve specific problems or needs: (1) ask
questions to identify problems or needs, (2) ask questions about the criteria and
constraints of the devices or solutions, (3) generate and communicate ideas for possible
devices or solutions, (4) build and test devices or solutions, (5) determine if the devices
or solutions solved the problem and refine the design if needed, and (6) communicate the
results.

0B924D8B1BDB4AD7AC2AF2927FD5305D.description:
Technology is any modification to the natural world created
to fulfill the wants and needs of humans. The engineering design process involves a series of
iterative steps used to solve a problem and often leads to the development of a new or improved
technology.

1BBDD9D92C974C82822F577AF1DE189B.description:
Obtain and evaluate informational texts, observations, data collected, or discussions to
(1) generate and answer questions, (2) understand phenomena, (3) develop models, or
(4) support explanations, claims, or designs. Communicate observations and
explanations using the conventions and expectations of oral and written language.

0DCC34DA1F794C5D9147FEE65DA2C383.description:
Construct scientific arguments to support claims, explanations, or designs using
evidence from observations, data, or informational texts.

5A931BEE339C4D3484FB72E70A3883D2.description:
Construct explanations of phenomena using (1) scientific evidence and models,
(2) conclusions from scientific investigations, (3) predictions based on observations and
measurements, or (4) data communicated in graphs, tables, or diagrams.

F03B24E408984CBDB2F7CED1E99B6E05.description:
Use mathematical and computational thinking to (1) express quantitative observations
using appropriate English or metric units, (2) collect and analyze data, or (3) understand
patterns, trends and relationships between variables.

8F7AF94DD40E43968D4CB34908523281.description:
Analyze and interpret data from informational texts, observations, measurements, or
investigations using a range of methods (such as tabulation or graphing) to (1) reveal
patterns and construct meaning or (2) support explanations, claims, or designs.

29BF1CC27173434D8EA67E9AC79AA881.description:
Plan and conduct scientific investigations to answer questions, test predictions and
develop explanations: (1) formulate scientific questions and predict possible outcomes,
(2) identify materials, procedures, and variables, (3) select and use appropriate tools or
instruments to collect qualitative and quantitative data, and (4) record and represent data
in an appropriate form. Use appropriate safety procedures.

650A4E15235C471AB69D418D94159147.description:
Develop, use, and refine models to (1) understand or represent phenomena, processes,
and relationships, (2) test devices or solutions, or (3) communicate ideas to others.

AA635606709A4D3D807581147B4CD8BE.description:
Ask questions that can be (1) answered using scientific investigations or (2) used to
refine models, explanations, or designs.

0464C04E181240CCBCE2B6C9E1968314.description:
The practices of science and engineering support the
development of science concepts, develop the habits of mind that are necessary for scientific
thinking, and allow students to engage in science in ways that are similar to those used by scientists
and engineers

461021F6AC4248A4A727F6FC130A5B86.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the locations, movements, and
patterns of stars and objects in the solar system.
